topic:
Certainly! Here is the structured information based on the user's research topic description:

1. **Main Topic**: 
   Investigating the causal relationship between supra-modal memory retention and activity in the Superior Parietal Cortex (SPC) by applying Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) and measuring changes in working memory performance in the presence or absence of distractors.

2. **Research Field**: 
   Neuroscience

3. **Specific Focus**: 
   Cognitive Neuroscience, with an emphasis on working memory and brain stimulation techniques.

4. **Methods**: 
   - Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS)
   - Behavioral experiments measuring working memory performance

5. **Keywords**: 
   - Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation
   - Superior Parietal Cortex
   - Working Memory
   - Distractors
   - Supra-modal Memory
   - Cognitive Neuroscience
   - Brain Stimulation

6. **PubMed Query**: 
   1. "Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation AND Superior Parietal Cortex AND Working Memory AND Distractors"
   2. "Working Memory AND Supra-modal Memory AND Superior Parietal Cortex"
   3. "Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation AND Cognitive Neuroscience AND Distractors AND Brain Stimulation"
   4. "Brain Stimulation AND Superior Parietal Cortex AND Working Memory"
   5. "TMS AND Supra-modal Memory AND Superior Parietal Cortex AND Distractors"

This structured information is designed to help facilitate a comprehensive literature search in PubMed and related academic databases.
query_used: ("Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation AND (Superior Parietal Cortex OR SPC) AND (Working Memory OR WM) AND Distractors") OR ("(Working Memory OR WM) AND (Supra-modal Memory) AND (Superior Parietal Cortex OR SPC)") OR ("Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation AND (Cognitive Neuroscience) AND Distractors AND (Brain Stimulation)") OR ("(Brain Stimulation) AND (Superior Parietal Cortex OR SPC) AND (Working Memory OR WM)") OR ("TMS AND (Supra-modal Memory) AND (Superior Parietal Cortex OR SPC) AND Distractors")

papers.title: High-Frequency rTMS Broadly Ameliorates Working Memory and Cognitive Symptoms in Stroke Patients: A Randomized Controlled Trial.
papers.apa_formatted: 1. Liu, Y., Ai, Y., Cao, J., Cheng, Q., Hu, H., Luo, J., Zeng, L., Zhang, S., Fang, J., Huang, L., Zheng, H., & Hu, X. (2024). High-frequency rTMS broadly ameliorates working memory and cognitive symptoms in stroke patients: A randomized controlled trial. *Neurorehabilitation and Neural Repair, 38*(10), 729-741. https://doi.org/10.1177/15459683241270022

papers.title: Frontoparietal tDCS Benefits Visual Working Memory in Older Adults With Low Working Memory Capacity.
papers.apa_formatted: 2. Arciniega, H., Gözenman, F., Jones, K. T., Stephens, J. A., & Berryhill, M. E. (2018). Frontoparietal tDCS benefits visual working memory in older adults with low working memory capacity. *Frontiers in Aging Neuroscience, 10*, 57. https://doi.org/10.3389/fnagi.2018.00057

papers.title: The Human Intraparietal Sulcus Modulates Task-Evoked Functional Connectivity.
papers.apa_formatted: 3. Hwang, K., Shine, J. M., Cellier, D., & D'Esposito, M. (2020). The human intraparietal sulcus modulates task-evoked functional connectivity. *Cerebral Cortex (New York, N.Y.: 1991), 30*(3), 875-887. https://doi.org/10.1093/cercor/bhz133

papers.title: Rhythmic TMS over parietal cortex links distinct brain frequencies to global versus local visual processing.
papers.apa_formatted: 4. Romei, V., Driver, J., Schyns, P. G., & Thut, G. (2011). Rhythmic TMS over parietal cortex links distinct brain frequencies to global versus local visual processing. *Current Biology: CB, 21*(4), 334-7. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2011.01.035

papers.title: Beta Oscillatory Dynamics in the Prefrontal and Superior Temporal Cortices Predict Spatial Working Memory Performance.
papers.apa_formatted: 5. Proskovec, A. L., Wiesman, A. I., Heinrichs-Graham, E., & Wilson, T. W. (2018). Beta oscillatory dynamics in the prefrontal and superior temporal cortices predict spatial working memory performance. *Scientific Reports, 8*(1), 8488. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-018-26863-x
